NORTHERN INDIANS.

We desire through our columns to call the attention of the Government to the condition of the Indians in the northern portion of this district. There are a large number of Indians in the northern part of this district who have other interests than those connected with the lands which they occupy. They have been treated with kindness and consideration by the Government, but they have not been able to secure the benefits promised them under the treaty. They should be treated with kindness and consideration, and their claims should be settled promptly. We urge upon the Government the claims of these Indians, and we hope that they will be treated with kindness and consideration.

NORTH WEST SENATORS.

The appointment of Mr. R. Hardisty of Edmonton to the Senate is a good one, and there has been considerable discussion as to whether he will be able to represent the interests of the Indians in the Senate. We believe that he will be able to do so, and we urge upon the Government to give him every possible assistance in carrying out his duties.

THE VAGRANCY CASE.

Sir, Please allow me to say that I have been informed that a case of vagrancy has been brought before the Court of Queen's Bench. The defendant is charged with being a vagrant, and the charge is supported by evidence. We urge upon the Government to take steps to prevent such cases from occurring in the future.

MOORE & MACDOWALL.
The great problems which must for many years engage the attention of the Northwest are problems of transporta-
tion. It is essential that the Government should approve of the scheme to secure a new line between Winnipeg and the United States, because it holds that the con-
struction of such a line would be a great
plighted faith, would divert trade to the
United States, which would be kept in
Canada, and injure the trade of Manitoba
and the Territories for the benefit of
Winnipeg, and would work injustice to
western Canada. The country needs new railways in unprovided dis-
tricts more urgently than it can com-
pensate for the loss of western Manitoba.

The Saskatchewan, especially its north branch, runs through the richest part of the Northwest. The soil for a thousand miles along its banks is as favorable as those of Manitoba, and the conditions are much more favorable to pioneer settlement. The Government has nothing to say in condemnation of the Canadian pioneers. They are as
easy as any in existence, and will in a few
years have made progress in their com-
munities. But the pioneer—especially the pioneer with limited means—finds
near the mouth of the river a better field
on the open prairie. On the latter he
has no lumber for his house, no water
till he digs a well far from the river's
source. Along the river he finds good
water in abundance, logs for the walls of
his house, and so soon as a decent house
is built, lumber is easily floated down
the river in snow.

The presence of timber does not diminish
the labor of clearing the land, for while
the soil of the river bank is fertile, the
other is arid. It is a singular fact
that that bank of the river which faces
the sun is always more productive than
the northern exposure is wooded. The the-
ory is that on the bank having a river
side exposure soil repetition occurs,
and there is a greater rate of expansion and contraction, which tear
the roots from the trees and destroy them.
On the bank facing south, or another
exposure the snow lies longer, protecting
the young trees and summer fairly sets
in on that side, thus promoting vegeta-
tion. At all events, whatever the theory
may be, the facts for the settler near a river
have been proven by experience. While
the prairie settler must spend considerable money for material with
which to build his house, he is doing
well. The settlers in Manitoba have
settled along the banks of rivers, and
those who emigrated to the prairies across
the river, and never regretted till they reached the Saskatchewan.

The importance of opening easy and
cheap communication with the West
of the Saskatchewan is manifest, and it is
certain that this communication should
be by rail. The Saskatchewan is naviga-
ble, and will be found to be extremely
useful to the settlers. Lake Winnipeg
is also navigable; but the route between
Winnipeg and Prince Albert is very
difficult and so difficult that a railway is an
absolute necessity. At the mouth of
the lake there is a river so wide that
there are six feet of water at low tide,
and above the mouth of the Saskatchewan
is a rapid wholly impassable by steam
boats, so that the steamer would have to
unload and send their passengers and
freight over a distance three or four
miles to the nearest point where river
boats. Even if a canal was built around this rapid, little benefit would
be derived from it because the light-
draught boats which navigate the
low river dare not venture out upon the
lake. Further, boats leaving Winnipeg
serve as habitations for the Indians, they
reach the neighborhood of Prince Albert,
while a railway will pass through a rich
country, and will be able to be com-
pleted and will then supply traffic to
the road. The Marquis and Northwestern
railways are now building a line westward
in the direction of Prince Albert, but
apparently the company finds it difficult
to raise funds to prosecute the work.
This scheme will probably be completed
by Federal aid might properly and benefi-
cially be extended, so that the line might
be extended to Prince Albert at the
earliest possible date.

Prince Albert is the natural gateway
to the rich lands further west of the
North Saskatchewan. But little habi-
tated country lies between it and Lake
Winnipeg; but west of it the land is
good, in the very base of the Rocky
Mountains. Routes ascend the river to
Edmonton, a distance of 600 miles above
Prince Albert, and these can supply set-
tlements at such times as the popula-
tion shall be strong enough to construct
a railway.

In course of time a railway must
be constructed from Prince Albert will become
necessary. Such a line will pass near
the mouth of Lake Winnipeg, touch the
Marquis line, and continue thence in a straight line to Quebec.
But this project must wait until
the Marquis line is completed. The
Saskatchewan valley at Prince Albert are ur-
gently needed, and to the solution of
this problem the people of only the
west of the old Canadian provinces
would give their best thought.—Hamilton
Spectator.

LOCAL NEWS.

T. O. Davis is not going out of busi-
ness, but expects to do legitimate trade.
On Wednesday evening Mr. A. Cole,
Mr. J. H. Smith, and Miss McNaughtan,
daughter of Mr. Wm. McNaughtan of the Lower
Town, attended the wedding of Miss
McNaughtan's father by the Rev. Mr. Campbell.
A number of the young people from the
Lower Town attended the ceremony.
The bride came to the church in a carriage
and was conducted to the church by her
father. After the ceremony she was
received by the Rev. Mr. Campbell.

Another wedding of Prince Albert's
young people have been joined together
in the happy bonds of matrimony. On
Saturday afternoon Mr. and Mrs. Neilson
led the altar Miss Kitty Ballantyne
whom the groomsman had tied to the
Rev. Mr. Campbell, after which they
were united in marriage by the officiating
Mr. Neilson whom they were
married by the P. A. C. band. We wish
every couple long life, happiness and
prosperity.

entertainment was given to the

were treated to a variety of songs and
were a partake of the hospitality of

P. T. BARNUM'S NEW STORY.

The opening chapters of a splendid
adventure for the young, by the famous show-
man, P. T. Barnum, appears this week
in the columns of The New York Family
Paper. It tells of the adventures of an American boy, whom
Mr. Barnum calls "My Plucky Boy Tom," who had to face the dangers of the
wild, and save animals to replace
those destroyed by the disastrous fire at
Barnum's Park last month. The reader is
thrilled by the heroics of this
dauntless American boy when cap-
tures the fiercest and wildest animals
ever to appear in the New York
Family Paper. This story is for
sale at all news-stands.
